data.title: In Praise of a Normal, Boring Country
data.meta_description: A cartoonist finds solace in Estonia's grit, thrift, and good cheer.
data.text:
A trip to Estonia

Last fall, my editors sent me to Brexit-Land. Now they've asked me to continue to explore Europe’s state of the union.

I see myself as someone who cares deeply about ‘‘European politics.’’

In reality, this means I’m glued to my Twitter feed during a spectacle like Brexit, gobbling down snarky think-pieces on some meaningless twist du jour.

Embarrassingly, a majority of the E.U. remains a foreign place to me. There are 27 member states, and I know the people, places and history of only a handful of them.

I looked at a map of Europe and picked the area I knew the least about:

The Baltic States!

I was especially curious about Estonia —

a former Soviet republic that, from afar, looks as though Silicon Valley and Scandinavia had a baby. It seemed like the hip cousin I didn’t know I had …

as opposed to Britain,

the drunk uncle I used to admire.

Based on a mix of journalistic masochism and genuine geographic curiosity, I decided to take a 27-hour bus trip from Berlin.

I had a lot of time to consider what I knew about the Baltics.

I realized I couldn’t name a single Baltic dish, building, invention or artist.

Come on! This couldn’t be.

I stared out the window.

Then I finally came up with a name:

Arvydas Sabonis. An N.B.A. player from Lithuania who played for the Portland Trail Blazers in the ’90s.

Not much, but I started digging.

Sabonis was one of four starters from Kaunas, Lithuania, who beat the Americans as part of the 1988 Soviet Olympic team.

Of course, nobody knew they were Lithuanian — they were Russians for all anyone in the West cared.

By 1992, Lithuania was free and wanted to send its own dream team to the Games in Barcelona.

Sabonis and a fellow teammate went looking for sponsors for their independent Olympic bid. They found a surprising donor:

the Grateful Dead.

The band supported the Lithuanian team financially and even designed a shirt for them. They won bronze!

In the early morning, as I rode through Lithuania, I was happily searching for backyard basketball hoops — proud to be on the same European team.

More than a day after boarding the bus, I finally arrived in Tallinn, Estonia’s capital.

The next morning, I got up early to explore the city.

I started my tour at the waterfront, where I discovered remnants of the 1980 Olympic Games.

Cool logo!

But for Estonians, Communist relics like this are a reminder of the nation’s most traumatic era,

when they lost their sovereignty and became part of the Soviet Union. During one week in 1949, Stalin deported nearly 3 percent of the population to Siberian gulags.

In September 1988, a staggering 300,000 people (that’s more than 20 percent of the entire population) gathered at the Tallinn Song Festival grounds and sang patriotic hymns, as a way to voice political dissent against the Soviet regime. They called it the Singing Revolution.

Finally, in 1991, Boris Yeltsin agreed to grant Estonia independence, though it took until 1994 for the last Russian troops to leave — and it happened only after President Lennart Meri forced the issue over a long, vodka-fueled lunch with Yeltsin. (Meri reportedly disposed of his drinks in a potted plant.)

Within 10 years of that lunch, Estonia had established a robust democracy and a thriving economy.

I asked a friend in Tallinn how his tiny nation managed to pull that off. He said Estonians are very pragmatic.

How can a country be pragmatic, you ask? Consider this quote from Meri in 1992:

The transformation from the Soviet to the E.U. era was visible as I walked through the city.

The outskirts still fit my stereotypical idea of drab Communist architecture.

The old city center, however, has been almost completely renovated. Everything is so quaint — the buildings might have been imported from a Swiss resort.

The same goes for the prices in the restaurants there, which puts them well out of reach for most Estonians.

One afternoon, I visited St. Nicholas’ Church, where I learned the story of the Flemish aristocrat Charles Eugène de Croy.

In 1702, de Croy died in Tallinn without repaying his considerable local debts.

The Estonians hoped to recoup some of the money from his relatives, but they refused, so the authorities denied him a proper funeral.

The corpse was kept in the church for years, where it eventually mummified, at which point they put it on public display for a fee.

De Croy’s body remained on view until the late 19th century, which offset at least some of what he owed the city.

This hard-core approach to debt has survived into the modern era. To achieve the financial benchmarks required to adopt the euro, which they did in 2011, Estonians put themselves through a tough cost-cutting regimen.

They drastically lowered government salaries and public spending and raised the age for pensions. Today, Estonia has by far the lowest government debt in the E.U. And Estonians are proud of their approach — they have passionate and public arguments with critics of austerity like Paul Krugman.

Saving money alone was not enough to create a viable economy. With limited natural resources and few established industries, Estonia saw its niche in becoming the most digitally advanced nation on earth.

The entire administration is digital. Almost everything can be done remotely, with automated systems that were designed and built in-house by the government itself. These innovations save the state an estimated 2 percent of G.D.P. annually.

The motivation seems to go beyond the financial payoff. The country’s leaders want to create a lean and effective form of government for the benefit of their citizens.

Imagine: no more waiting at the D.M.V. Ever.

Estonia defies my political stereotypes. As in most E.U. countries, there has been a troubling surge in right-wing populism, but the people remain steadfastly enthusiastic about the E.U.

With its aversion to regulation and deficit spending, Estonia can seem like a utopia for neoliberals, but then the government pursues an ambitious progressive agenda, including some of the most generous terms for paid maternal leave in the world.

As I started packing for my return home, I thought about how — for thousands of years — countries have defined success and glory by crushing enemies and creating empires.

Having been on the receiving end of such ambitions until very recently, Estonia seems to have developed a different idea of success.

I left Tallinn by ferry to head to Finland. A generation ago, this would have been like traveling to an enemy kingdom, with long lines and hostile border guards. Not today.

As I had breakfast aboard the ferry, I thought of what Meri said when he stepped down as president in 2001: ‘‘I hand over a normal, boring country.’’

In early 2020, I think there is no sexier vision than that of a ‘‘normal and boring’’ life: reliable institutions, social equality, a sound economy, and freedom from climate armageddon.

Fighting for such things is exactly what the E.U. is supposed to do. What an audacious goal.

Postscript: I went on this trip late last year. The past few weeks have (temporarily, I hope) changed everything: Borders are closed, discussions about austerity are paused and we are all dreaming of normal and boring days that start with dropping off our kids at school and end with meeting a few friends at a restaurant. Rebuilding our economies and our political institutions will be daunting. For now, in Europe, this struggle is taking place on a national level. We will find out soon if the E.U. can play the important role it was created for.

I will continue my investigation.

&nbsp

Acknowledgements: Thank you to Scott Diel, Johannes Thimm and Marko Mäetamm for their insight into Estonian people and culture.

Story & art by Christoph Niemann

Correction:

An earlier version of this article misstated two dates. Estonia adopted the euro in 2011, not 2004. Lennart Meri stepped down as president in 2001, not 1997.
